subject: RE: [junit] Re: assertEquals
msgSnippet: it seems to me that there must be a problem in the implementation of the equals method. If you are checking to see if the varibles point at the same memory
messageBody:
it seems to me that there must be a problem in the
implementation of the "equals" method. If you are
checking to see if the varibles point at the same
memory space then you should be using assertSame().

No?
Patrick


--- "Pritchard, Sean" <sean.pritchard@...> wrote:
> It is possible that you have a classloader problem.
> The classloader is
> "secretly" prepended to the fully qualified class
> name of an object. This
> will generally result in an instaceof call returning
> false. Most
> object.equals() methods first do an instance of
> check and return false if
> the objects are not of the same class type.
> We have had cases where a JUnit test puts an object
> on a JMS message
> queue, then retrieves it and check it for equality.
> This test fails when
> JUnit's class reloading is turned on, but succeeds
> when class reloading is
> disabled.
>
> Sean
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: benjamin@...
> [mailto:benjamin@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, October 23, 2001 9:54 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: assertEquals
>
>

System.out.println(aCountry.isIdentical(aJurisdiction.getCountry()));

ethenticate/Country:com.notuskey.persistence.whoWhere.CountryPK@e0
